results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Film Collection: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

This short film, originally shot on 9.5mm film, features panoramic views over city buildings; a busy street in Melbourne (possibly Collins St) full of 1920s cars and trams, and decorated with banners for the royal visit of Prince Albert, Duke of York and the Duchess of York; the docks; a squadron of planes flying overhead; and the royal parade down a main boulevard.

results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Film Collection: Reel 6]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

This short film, originally shot on 9.5mm film, features an array of clips of landscape; a 1920s car with a man pouring a drink into a cup; a horse and plough in a field; and a man on a rock formation (possibly Mount Gambier in South Australia).

results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Film Collection: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

This short film, originally shot on 9.5mm film, shows a group of people in 1920s fashion walking towards the camera, smiling and posing for the camera with a pet cat and dog. It also features two women with bobbed hair, a child playing with a rattle, and a dog in front of a house.

results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Film Collection: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

This short film, originally shot on 9.5mm film, shows a parade with a marching band through a country town past a garage called Bridge Motors (likely Duigan’s garage in Yarrawonga), followed by a couple in a rowboat and a group of people cavorting on the banks of a river or lake wearing 1920s fashion.

results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Film Collection: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

This short film, originally shot on 9.5mm film, features panoramic views of the Red Rock Lakes near Colac, Victoria. The film features shots of a man and child on a hill, with the man holding a film camera, and shots of Duigan’s brother, Reginald Duigan, and children outside a large house.

results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Film Collection: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. This short film, originally shot on 9.5mm film, features shots of Wannon Gorge and Nigretta Falls (formerly known as Upper Wannon Falls) in the Grampians, Victoria.

results.title: Stelarc Moving Image Collection
results.brief_description:
The Stelarc Collection is the moving image archive of Australian performance artist Stelarc. The collection consists of documentation of events and performances throughout the career of the pioneering body artist from the 1970s to the 2000s. Renowned for pushing his body to its limits through durational performance, body modification and surgical enhancement, Stelarc has established a decades-long practice that explores the intersection between the human body and technology, proposing a post-human understanding of the world. This unique archive of video and photographic documentation spans the artist’s early hook suspensions and internal body probes to performances with a robotic third arm and experiments in virtual realities.

The collection is housed on a variety of formats used since the introduction of video in the 1970s, including reel-to-reel tape, VHS, U-Matic, SP Betacam and Mini DV. These variable formats are currently being digitised to ensure the preservation and legacy of the artist’s archive.

The Stelarc Collection has been generously donated to ACMI by the artist through the Cultural Gifts Program.

images.caption: [Stelarc: Event for Modified Man 1976] (Stelarc) Digital Access Still

results.title: [Stelarc: Event for Modified Man 1976]
results.brief_description:
This video is documentation of a performance entitled “Modulate / Meditate: Event for Modified Man” held at Tamura Gallery in Tokyo, Japan, from 26 January to 1 February 1976.

In this durational performance, Stelarc has hooks inserted into his back and sews first his lips and then his eyelids closed with a needle and thread. In the gallery are TV monitors including one showing an X-ray of his own body. Standing in the centre of the gallery with the hooks attached to the wall behind him, the artist captures the sounds of his own body – heartbeat, breath and blood rushing – which are then amplified throughout the space. In the latter part of the video, the participation of the body comes to an end: the artist removes the stitches from his eyelids and mouth and the hooks are removed.

This performance was originally filmed on 1/2 inch videotape.
